title: Phrack Loopback
historical_context: This article serves as a forum for discussions and reviews within the hacker community, reflecting the culture and concerns of the early 1990s.
target_audience: Hackers, phreakers, security professionals, and those interested in hacker culture.
short_summary: Phrack Loopback provides a platform for readers to discuss various topics, share concerns, and review items of interest in the hacker community. This issue includes a review of 2600 Magazine and discussions on various hacker-related topics.
summary:
Phrack Loopback is an interactive section of the Phrack zine where readers can engage with the staff and each other on a variety of topics. This issue features a review of 2600 Magazine, highlighting its unique articles on hacking, phreaking, and even some unexpected topics like postal hacking and psychological insights into the hacker community. The review praises 2600 for its quality content and encourages submissions from readers, which can earn them a free subscriptionâ€”a clever way to engage the community.

Additionally, the article touches on the controversial figure Dale Drew, a former informant for the Secret Service, who attempted to subscribe to Phrack. This sparked a strong response from the community, showcasing the tension between hackers and law enforcement. The piece encapsulates the spirit of the time, where the hacker community was both vibrant and wary of outside influences, making it a relevant read for those interested in the evolution of hacker culture and its ongoing challenges.
